an10.75.blurb: The female lay disciple Migasālā questions Ānanda how the Buddha could have declared her father and her uncle had the same level of spiritual attainment, when one was much more strict than the other. Ānanda conveys this to the Buddha, who responds that only such as he can pass judgment, since the spiritual faculties of individuals are complex and hard to understand.

an10.216.blurb: Those who do the ten kinds of bad deeds are like creepy creatures.

an10.55.blurb: Sāriputta explains what the Buddha meant by a mendicant who is in decline.

an10.67.blurb: At Naḷakapāna the Buddha invites Sāriputta to teach. He speaks of ten qualities that lead to decline or non-decline.

an10.175.blurb: Through the teaching one may avoid the various kinds of bad deeds.

an10-sacittavagga.translated_title: The Chapter on Your Own Mind

an10.20.blurb: Ten noble abodes in which the noble ones of the past, present and future abide, in detail.

an10.172.blurb: One should understand what is the teaching and what is contrary to the teaching. After hearing this in brief from the Buddha, the mendicants seek a detailed answer from Mahākaccāna.

an10.52.blurb: Sāriputta teaches that, if you can’t read anyone else’s mind, read your own by regular self-reflection.

an10.66.blurb: Sāriputta explains to the wanderer Sāmaṇḍakāni that dissatisfaction is suffering, enjoyment is happiness.

an10.50.blurb: Some monks are arguing, so the Buddha teaches them ten warm-hearted principles.

an10.229-232.translated_title: Untitled Discourses on Ten to Forty Qualities (2nd)

an10.148.translated_title: The Teaching of the True Persons

an10.35.blurb: Ten qualities a mendicant should have to give dependence.

an10.34.blurb: Ten qualities a mendicant should have to give ordination.

an10.104.blurb: When a person has wrong view, all their path development is wrong. But when they have right view, everything good follows.

an10.25.blurb: Ten universal dimensions of meditation, or kasiṇas.

an10.109.blurb: The Buddha speaks of a emetic for curing ailments, but says that a spiritual emetic is better.

an10.167.blurb: The Buddha sees Jāṇussoṇī observing the brahmanical ceremony of “descent”. The Buddha teaches his revised version.

an10.114.blurb: One should understand what is the teaching and what is contrary to the teaching, in detail.

an10.4.blurb: Sāriputta teaches how, like a tree that grows due to its leaves, liberation follows when ethics is present.

an10.10.translated_title: Inspiring All Around: the Three Knowledges
an10.10.blurb: Ten factors, beginning with faith, that a mendicant should fulfill.

an10.44.blurb: A mendicant who wishes to admonish another should first reflect on five things in themselves and establish a further five.

an10.173.blurb: One should understand what is the teaching and what is contrary to the teaching, in detail.

an10.220.blurb: The Buddha teaches a brahmin that bad conduct leads to hell, good conduct to heaven.

an10.82.blurb: A mendicant cannot achieve progress if they have ten bad qualities starting with lack of faith.

an10.110.blurb: The ten path factors each expel their opposite.

an10.233-236.translated_title: Untitled Discourses on Ten to Forty Qualities (3rd)

an10.23.blurb: Some things are to be given by body, others by speech, and still others by wisdom.

an10.87.blurb: The Buddha, speaking in reference to the monk Kalandaka, explains ten qualities that lead to discord or unity.

an10.111.blurb: An adept has fulfilled the ten path factors.

an10.103.blurb: The tenfold wrong path leads to failure, the tenfold right path leads to success.

an10.46.blurb: The Sakyans say that they don’t always observe the eight precepts on the sabbath. The Buddha strongly admonishes them to be more consistent.

an10.115.blurb: One should understand what is the teaching and what is contrary to the teaching. After hearing this in brief from the Buddha, the mendicants seek a detailed answer from Ānanda.

an10.8.blurb: Ten factors, beginning with faith, that a mendicant should fulfill.

an10.120.blurb: The Buddha teaches his revised version of the brahmanical ceremony of “descent” to the mendicants.

an10.62.blurb: Even though craving has no discernible first point, it still has a cause.

an10.99.blurb: When Upāli asks to go into retreat, the Buddha warns him that secluded wilderness dwellings are hard to endure unless one is accomplished in meditation. He gives a long account of the training required before going into solitude, and ends by encouraging Upāli to stay in the Saṅgha.

an10.168.blurb: The Buddha teaches his revised version of the brahmanical ceremony of “descent” to the mendicants.

an10.54.blurb: The Buddha teaches that, if you can’t read anyone else’s mind, read your own by regular self-reflection. Includes a teaching on various things that should or should not be cultivated.

an10.48.translated_title: Ten Regular Reflections for a Renunciate
an10.48.blurb: Topics for frequent reflection by one gone forth.

an10.13.blurb: Five lower and five higher fetters.

an10.106.blurb: Each of the ten path factors wears away its opposite.

an10.218.blurb: The Buddha asserts that one’s kamma must be exhausted before making an end of suffering. This statement precedes a long explanation of deeds and their causes.

an10.21.blurb: Like a lion, a Realized One roars his preeminence based on ten powers.

an10.89.blurb: The monk Kokālika accuses Sāriputta and Moggallāna of having evil wishes. The Buddha defends them. Later, Kokālika suffers calamity and is reborn in hell.

an10.84.blurb: When a mendicant declares enlightenment, the Buddha or another accomplished meditator examines them.

an10.116.blurb: The wanderer Ajita informs the Buddha that a philosopher has proposed 500 cases for knowing that and argument has been won or lost. The Buddha asks the mendicants about these.

an10-akankhavagga.translated_title: The Chapter on If You Want

an10-karajakayavagga.translated_title: The Chapter on the Body Born of Deeds

an10.11.blurb: Five factors that a mendicant should have, and five factors of a lodging that they should occupy.

an10.36.blurb: Ten qualities a mendicant should have to be attended by a novice.

an10.85.blurb: Venerable Mahācunda teaches that when a mendicant boasts about spiritual attainments, the Buddha or another accomplished meditator examines them.

an10.24.blurb: Venerable Mahācunda teaches that, though a mendicant might claim to be free of greed, hate, and delusion, this is not always the case.

an10.33.blurb: Ten qualities a mendicant should have to be appointed to judge a dispute.

an10.97.translated_title: Worthy of Offerings Dedicated to the Gods
an10.97.blurb: With ten qualities, a mendicant is worthy.

an10.22.blurb: The Buddha claims to be assured regarding the various different doctrinal hypotheses, based on the ten powers.

an10.19.blurb: Ten noble abodes in which the noble ones of the past, present and future abide.

an10.41.blurb: Ten reasons for disputes in the Saṅgha.

an10.122.blurb: The ten path factors lead to the end of the defilements.

an10.16.translated_title: Worthy of Offerings Dedicated to the Gods

an10.30.blurb: King Pasenadi returns victorious from battle and immediately goes to see the Buddha, bowing reverentially to his feet, and declaring ten reasons for his love and devotion to the Buddha.

an10.86.blurb: Venerable Mahākassapa teaches that when a mendicant declares enlightenment, the Buddha or another accomplished meditator examines them.

an10.169.blurb: The Buddha teaches the brahmin Saṅgārava that the wrong path is the near shore where most people dwell; the right path is the far shore, where few have crossed over.

an10.119.blurb: The Buddha sees Jāṇussoṇī observing the brahmanical ceremony of “descent”. The Buddha teaches his revised version.

an10.47.blurb: Mahāli the Licchavi asks the Buddha for the causes of bad deeds.

an10.102.blurb: The seven factors of awakening lead to realizing the three knowledges.

an10-samanasannavagga.translated_title: The Chapter on Perceptions for Ascetics

an10.71.blurb: If a mendicant wishes to attain spiritual heights, they should begin by practicing the code of training rules.

an10.83.blurb: Venerable Puṇṇiya asks why the Buddha sometimes feels like teaching, other times not.

an10.5.blurb: Ānanda teaches how, like a tree that grows due to its leaves, liberation follows when ethics is present.

an10.31.blurb: The Buddha teaches Venerable Upāli the ten reasons for establishing the training rules.

an10.42.blurb: Ten roots for disputes in the Saṅgha.

an10.9.translated_title: Inspiring All Around: the Peaceful Liberations
an10.9.blurb: Ten factors, beginning with faith, that a mendicant should fulfill.

an10.32.translated_title: Suspending the Recitation of the Monastic Code
an10.32.blurb: Ten reasons for suspending the recitation of the code of conduct.

an10.91.blurb: The Buddha teaches Anāthapiṇḍika ten kinds of persons who enjoy sensual pleasures.

an10.95.blurb: The wanderer Uttiya asks the Buddha a series of ten metaphysical questions as to whether the cosmos is finite, etc. The Buddha responds by saying that he only teaches the end of suffering. Uttiya goes on to ask whether all beings will be liberated. The Buddha is silent, and Ānanda answers on his behalf.

an10.192.translated_title: The Teaching of the True Persons

an10.112.blurb: An adept has fulfilled the ten path factors.

an10.179.translated_title: The Teaching of the Noble Ones

an10.61.blurb: Even though ignorance has no discernible first point, it still has a cause.

an10.43.blurb: Ten roots for disputes in the Saṅgha.

an10-ariyavagga.translated_title: The Chapter on the Noble Path

an10.3.blurb: The Buddha teaches how, like a tree that grows due to its leaves, liberation follows when ethics is present.

an10.217.blurb: The Buddha asserts that one’s kamma must be exhausted before making an end of suffering. This statement precedes a long explanation of deeds and their causes.

an10.1.blurb: The purpose of ethics, leading step by step to liberation.

an10.174.blurb: The various kinds of bad deeds are caused by greed, hate, and delusion.

an10.211.blurb: The ten kinds of bad deeds lead you to hell; the ten good deeds to heaven.

an10.15.blurb: Diligence is the foremost of all good qualities.

an10-ariyamaggavagga.translated_title: The Chapter on the Noble Path

an10.6.blurb: Ānanda asks the Buddha about a mysterious state of immersion in meditation where there is no normal perception, yet one is still conscious.

an10.196.translated_title: Principles That Should Be Made Much Of

an10.2.blurb: There’s no need to make a wish to get enlightened; it happens naturally when the conditions are there.

an10.40.blurb: The Buddha teaches Ānanda the ten reasons for harmony in the Saṅgha, as well as the outcome of creating harmony.

an10.100.blurb: Ten things must be given up before attaining perfection.

an10.29.blurb: Starting with a comparison with the King of Kosala, the Buddha teaches a series of ten advanced teachings. He culminates by affirming that he teaches the full understanding of sensual pleasures, forms, and feelings.

an10.65.blurb: Sāriputta explains to the wanderer Sāmaṇḍakāni that rebirth is suffering, freedom from rebirth is happiness.

an10.53.blurb: The Buddha doesn’t praise stagnation in wholesome qualities, let alone decline.

an10.70.blurb: The monks are sitting around chatting about this and that. The Buddha admonishes them and teaches ten grounds of praise.

an10.90.translated_title: The Powers of One Who has Ended Defilements
an10.90.blurb: Ten powers by which a mendicant knows that they have ended the defilements.

an10.176.blurb: Cunda the smith tells the Buddha of rites of purification practiced by the western brahmins. The Buddha explains purification in his teaching.

an10.171.blurb: One should understand what is the teaching and what is contrary to the teaching, in brief.

an10.93.blurb: Anāthapiṇḍika visits some wanderers, who ask him about the Buddha’s views. Anāthapiṇḍika asks them to explain their own view first. He then declares his own understanding of impermanence, leaving the wanderers speechless.

an10.37.blurb: Ten reasons for schism in the Saṅgha.

an10.45.blurb: Ten dangers for a monk who enters a royal harem.

an10.51.blurb: The Buddha teaches that, if you can’t read anyone else’s mind, read your own by regular self-reflection.

an10.170.blurb: The wrong path is the near shore where most people dwell; the right path is the far shore, where few have crossed over.

an10-paccorohanivagga.translated_title: The Chapter on the Ceremony of Descent

an10.27.blurb: Some wanderers claim to teach the direct knowledge of all things, just like the Buddha. However the Buddha disputes this by presenting ten “Great Questions” that they cannot answer.

an10.118.blurb: The wrong path is the near shore where most people dwell; the right path is the far shore, where few have crossed over.

an10.78.blurb: Jain ascetics have ten bad qualities.

an10.7.blurb: Ānanda asks Sāriputta about a mysterious state of immersion in meditation where there is no normal perception, yet one is still conscious. Sāriputta confirms that there is, and claims to have attained it.

an10.77.blurb: A bad monk has ten bad qualities, like a crow.

an10.26.blurb: The female lay follower Kāḷī of Kuraraghara in Avantī asks Venerable Mahākaccāna about a verse spoken by the Buddha in “The Maidens’ Questions” (SN 4.25). He replies in terms of the ten universal dimensions of meditation.

an10.59.blurb: Ten reflections that strengthen the mind of a renunciate.

an10.107.blurb: The Buddha speaks of a southern land called “Bath”, but says that a spiritual bath is better.

an10.17.blurb: Ten qualities that serve as protector.

an10.88.blurb: A mendicant who insults their spiritual companions incurs ten disasters.

an10.64.blurb: Stream-enterers may realize the final goal in this life or the next.

an10.14.blurb: Five kinds of emotional barrenness and five emotional shackles.

an10.73.blurb: Ten desirable things that are hard to get.

an10.177.blurb: Jāṇussoṇī describes brahmanical memorial rites for the dead, and asks if sharing merit actually benefits dead relatives. The Buddha replies that it might do in some circumstances.

an10.117.blurb: The wrong path is the near shore where most people dwell; the right path is the far shore, where few have crossed over.

an10.39.blurb: The Buddha teaches Ānanda the ten reasons for schism in the Saṅgha, as well as the outcome of causing schism.

an10.108.blurb: The Buddha speaks of a purgative for curing ailments, but says that a spiritual purgative is better.

an10.92.blurb: A noble disciple has eliminated five perils, realized the four factors of stream-entry, and seen the noble process.

an10.63.blurb: Those who have certainty in the Buddha may realize the final goal in this life or the next.

an10.49.blurb: Ten things that depend on the body.

an10.28.blurb: Some lay people ask the nun from Kajaṅgalā regarding the ten “Great Questions”. Though she has not heard this teaching herself, she explains from her own understanding, and is praised by the Buddha.

an10.81.blurb: Giving up ten things, the Buddha lives free of limits.

an10.57.blurb: Ten meditative perceptions that lead to the deathless.

an10.105.blurb: Ignorance is the precursor of wrong view and the other bad qualities, while right view is the opposite.

an10.113.blurb: One should understand what is the teaching and what is contrary to the teaching, in brief.

an10.69.blurb: The monks are sitting around chatting about this and that. The Buddha admonishes them and teaches ten topics of conversation suitable for mendicants.

an10.72.blurb: When the Buddha receives noisy visitors, several monks withdraw to a nearby forest to meditate. The Buddha praises them, saying that noise is a thorn to absorption.

an10.56.blurb: Ten meditative perceptions that lead to the deathless.

an10.60.blurb: The monk Girimānanda is sick. The Buddha encourages Ānanda to visit him and speak of ten perceptions.

an10.18.blurb: Ten qualities that serve as protector, in detail.

an10.58.blurb: The root of all things, and similar principles.

an10.121.blurb: As the dawn is the forerunner of the sunrise, right view is the forerunner of the path.

an10.98.blurb: With ten qualities, a senior mendicant is at ease wherever they live.

an10.96.blurb: The wanderer Kokanada meets Ānanda at the baths and engages him on the topic of the ten metaphysical questions.

an10.135.translated_title: The Teaching of the Noble Ones

an10.101.blurb: Three ascetic perceptions lead to seven results.

an10.12.blurb: A mendicant should abandon the five hindrances and possess the five factors of the adept.

an10.38.blurb: Ten reasons for harmony in the Saṅgha.

an10.76.blurb: Without rebirth, old age, and death, there would be no teaching of Dhamma. The Buddha teaches a series of sets of three things leading to liberation.

an10.219.blurb: The Buddha asserts that one’s kamma must be exhausted before making an end of suffering. If one develops the heart’s release through love, no bad deeds can persist there.

an10.225-228.translated_title: Untitled Discourses on Ten to Forty Qualities (1st)

an10.68.blurb: At Naḷakapāna the Buddha invites Sāriputta to teach. He speaks of ten qualities that lead to decline or non-decline.

an10.94.blurb: The householder Vajjiyamāhita visits some wanderers, who accuse the Buddha of condemning all asceticism. Vajjiyamāhita counters this by saying the Buddha only criticizes what is worthy of criticism. The Buddha praises him, and explains in detail what this means.

an11.1.blurb: Good conduct leads to non-regret, to joy, and so on all the way to liberation.

an.blurb: The “Numbered” or “Numerical” Discourses are usually known as Aṅguttara Nikāya in Pali, abbreviated AN. However, the Pali tradition also knows the form Ekottara (“one-up” or “incremental”), and this is the form usually found in the northern collections. These collections organize texts in numbered sets, from one to eleven. Compared to the other nikāyas, they are more oriented to the lay community. The Ekottarikāgama (EA) in Chinese is a highly unusual text, which features a range of variations within itself when it comes even to basic doctrines. It shares considerably less in common with the Pali Aṅguttara than the other collections do with their counterparts. In addition, there is a partial Ekottarikāgama in Chinese, as well as a variety of individual discourses and fragments in Chinese and Sanskrit.
